title: 105_hr1733
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Saint Helena Island National Scenic Area Act" and establishes the Saint Helena Island National Scenic Area. The Saint Helena Island National Scenic Area Act aims to preserve the resources and values of Saint Helena Island in Lake Michigan, Michigan. It establishes the Saint Helena Island National Scenic Area for conservation, protection, and enhancement of recreation opportunities, habitat, vegetation, and historical resources. The Act will be effective upon conveyance of the island to the United States, except for a portion to be conveyed to the Great Lakes Lighthouse Keepers Association. The Great Lakes Lighthouse Keepers Association is mentioned in the Coast Guard Authorization Act of 1996. The scenic area on Saint Helena Island in Lake Michigan, Michigan, and surrounding areas will be included in the Hiawatha National Forest boundaries. Lands acquired by the United States under this Act will be treated as entitlement lands for payments to local governments. Administration and management of the area will be established. The Secretary of Agriculture will administer the scenic area on Saint Helena Island in Lake Michigan in accordance with National Forest System laws. Within 3 years, a management plan will be developed as an amendment to the Hiawatha National Forest plan, addressing special management considerations. The scenic area on Saint Helena Island in Lake Michigan will have special management considerations, including alternative public access, no new permanent roads, and restrictions on timber harvest except for necessary purposes. The Secretary may engage in vegetation manipulation for wildlife habitat and visual quality. The scenic area on Saint Helena Island in Lake Michigan will have special management considerations, including restrictions on timber harvest for maintenance of wildlife habitat and visual quality. Motorized travel is not permitted within the scenic area, except on Lake Michigan waters. Wildfires will be suppressed in a manner consistent with the Act's purposes, and insect and disease outbreaks may be controlled to maintain scenic quality. The Secretary will provide docking facilities through concession, permit, or other means. The Secretary will provide docking facilities through concession, permit, or other means consistent with the management plan. Safety measures will be taken for public health and protection of the scenic area in case of fire, insect infestation, or disease. Consultation with State and local officials, public participation, and consideration of all views will be done in preparing the comprehensive management plan. SEC. 5. FISH AND GAME.

Michigan retains jurisdiction over fish and wildlife in the scenic area.

SEC. 6. MINERALS.

Lands in the scenic area are withdrawn from mining and mineral leasing laws, except for common minerals for road construction.

SEC. 7. ACQUISITION. The Secretary is authorized to acquire lands, waters, and structures within the scenic area for the purposes of the Act. Additionally, lands or structures on the mainland may be acquired for access and administrative facilities. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums may be appropriated for land acquisition, structures, and development within the scenic area and mainland for access and administrative facilities.
